Detailed Description

Definition of a "LRU algorithm".

The following class defines a list -- a double linked list of LRU elements, each of which points to a single item. The first element is the "older" one The last element is the "younger" one

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

LRU::LRU (  int  max  ) 
 

Constructor. Initialize the LRU.

Initialize the list, empty to start with. Elements can now be added to the list.

Parameters:
max if the maximum size of the list

LRU::~LRU (   ) 
 

Destructor. De-allocate the LRU.

Prepare a LRU for deallocation. If the LRU still contains any LRUElements, de-allocate them. However, note that we do *not* de-allocate the "items" on the LRU -- this module allocates and de-allocates the LRUElements to keep track of each item, but a given item may be on multiple LRUs, so we can't de-allocate them here.

void LRU::Flush (   ) 
 

Flush the list.

Reinitialize the list, empty to start with. Elements can now be added to the list.

LRUElement * LRU::NewElement (  int  value  )  [private]
 

Add a new element in the list, put out the older one if the list is full (first of the list). The new element become the last of the list (thge tounger one)

Returns:
the index of the element, which was put out -1 if no element was put out.

int LRU::Use (  int  value  ) 
 

Called when using member number "value".

Look for the element in the list and put it at the end.

Parameters:
value is the index of the element
Returns:
-1 if the index > size of the list, 0 if all is ok

int LRU::WantOldest (   ) 
 

Called when wanting the value of the oldest element of the list.

Look for the oldest elemnt of the list or an empty case

Returns:
the index (-1 if an error occured)
